newsitem.title: UK: IPE says time not right for elecricity contract.
newsitem.headline: IPE says time not right for elecricity contract.

text.p: International Petroleum Exchange (IPE) said Thursday the right market conditions for the launch of an electricity futures contract were not yet in place in the U.K.

This conclusion was reached at a meeting hosted by the Exchange on Thursday with representatives from regional electricity companies (RECs), power generators, traders and the industry regulator, the IPE said in a statement.

Those present at the meeting felt that while the U.K. electricity market is characterised by high price volatility and risk, a number of other preconditions for a successful futures contract --including a stable political and regulatory environment -- were yet to be met.

"Far reaching reforms are being made in the electricity market next year, and the future development of the industry is unclear, particularly given the recent change of government," the statement said.
The current pricing mechanism of the electricity Pool and its lack of demand side bidding was also cited as an obstacle to the development of the market, the IPE said.
"The IPE would like to launch an electricity futures contract as soon as the time is right," said IPE chief executive Lynton Jones.

"But we do not want to jeopardise the success of such a contract by premature action...when conditions allow and the industry feels the time is right, we will be prepared and ready to take the initiative."
